column1: Seinäjoki is a city located in South Ostrobothnia
column2: Finland.  Seinäjoki originated around the Östermyra bruk iron and gunpowder factories founded in 1798. Seinäjoki became a municipality in 1868
column3: market town in 1931 and town in 1960. In 2005
column4: the municipality of Peräseinäjoki was merged into Seinäjoki

column2: Lakeuden Risti Church and central administrative buildings are designed by Alvar Aalto.

column1: The asteroid 1521 Seinäjoki bears the town's name.
Seinäjoki was historically called Östermyra in Swedish. Today this name
column3: is very seldom used even among the Swedish speakers. Literal translation for Seinäjoki is "Wallriver".

column1: Seinäjoki Airport is located in the neighbouring municipality of Ilmajoki
column2: 11 kilometres (10 mi) south of the Seinäjoki city centre. Seinäjoki railway station in city center was opened in 1883 and until 1897 it carried the name Östermyra station.

column1: Seinäjoki is home to SJK Seinäjoki
column2: a professional football team that competes in the Finnish Veikkausliiga. SJK is one of the top football teams in Finland.

column1: Seinäjoki has grown around a few important railroad crossings. The Tampere – Vaasa railway
column4: along with the Kokkola track that was opened for rail service in 1885
column5: and the Kristiinankaupunki track which had been completed in 1913
column6: raised Seinäjoki as an important railway crossing section in Finland. In the early 1970s
column7: a direct railway between Tampere and Seinäjoki was opened
column8: and the services of Seinäjoki improved further.
